item.title: Mario: Less comfortable
item.description: World 1-1 Toward the end of World 1-1 in Nintendo’s Super Mario Brothers, Mario must ascend a right-aligned pyramid of blocks, as shown below. Let’s recreate that pyramid in C, albeit in text, using hashes (#) for bricks, a la the below. Each hash is a bit taller than it is wide (at least for the font we’re using), so the pyramid itself will also appear taller than it is wide.

item.title: Mario: More comfortable
item.description: World 1-1 Toward the beginning of World 1-1 in Nintendo’s Super Mario Brothers, Mario must hop over adjacent pyramids of blocks, as shown below. Let’s recreate those pyramids in C, albeit in text, using hashes (#) for bricks, a la the below. Each hash is a bit taller than it is wide (at least for the font we’re using), so the pyramids themselves will also appear taller than they are wide.

item.title: Hello
item.description: A simple assignment to practice testing and submitting your code.

item.title: Practice: sum.c
item.description: Write a program called sum.c that asks the user to provide ten integers as input and computes the sum.

<!DOCTYPE html> Mario Mario (less comfortable) World 1-1 Toward the end of World 1-1 in Nintendo's Super Mario Brothers, Mario must climb a right-aligned pyramid of blocks, as shown below. Let's recreate that pyramid in Python, by using hashes (#) for bricks, like shown below. Each hash is a bit taller than it is wide (at least for the font we're using), so the pyramid itself will also appear taller than it is wide.

<!DOCTYPE html> Mario Mario (more comfortable) World 1-1 Toward the beginning of World 1-1 in Nintendo's Super Mario Brothers, Mario must hop over adjacent pyramids of blocks, as shown below. Let's recreate those pyramids in Python, using hashes (#) for bricks, like shown below. Each hash is a bit taller than it is wide (at least for the font we're using), so the pyramids themselves will also appear taller than they are wide.

<!doctype html> Massive Massive Make this circuit in Tinkercad: This circuit uses chips called logic gates. Setting the switches will turn on/off the attached lights. You need to set the switches to the correct pattern. To answer to this challenge you must look for an 8 letter word on a certain teacher's class Schoology page. The right pattern of lights will lead you to them. Teacher ON ON Math ON OFF English OFF ON History OFF OFF Science Put the word you found in the URL for the answer to this puzzle.
<!doctype html> Method Congratulations, you found it! Remember this number: 614

<!doctype html> Overrun Overrun The following ciphertext was created using the same steps you used in the RSA worksheet, but with bigger numbers. Ciphertext:  In order to decrypt it, you'll need D, which means you have to find which numbers I chose for p and q, the prime numbers that start everything off. The value I used for E is 257. Fill in the blanks: p q m A E 257 D Once you've got m and D, you can use this Python program for decryption.

<!doctype html> Particle Particle The solution to this puzzle is encoded here: 1070:12:1:2 259:6:5:8 74:3:6:3 673:16:2:3 436:2:5:4 1108:5:1:5 387:21:8:6 915:17:3:1 For the answer, put the decoded word into the URL. Hints: Ottendorf

<!doctype html> Massive Massive Make this circuit in Tinkercad: This circuit uses chips called logic gates. Setting the switches will turn on/off the attached lights. You need to set the switches to the correct pattern. To answer to this challenge you must look for an 8 letter word on a certain teacher's class Schoology page. The right pattern of lights will lead you to them. Teacher ON ON Math ON OFF Science OFF ON History OFF OFF English Put the word you found in the URL for the answer to this puzzle.

<!doctype html> Rebellion Rebellion Secrecy isn't just about making a message hard for an unauthorized person to read, it also helps if you can hide it where it can't be found! For example, use your mouse to highlight below to find some text hiding in plain sight: Where else could information be hidden? You won't be able to continue until you find the source of your next clue.
<!doctype html> Rebuttal Congratulations, you found it! The value of Y is 7

<!doctype html> SQL Murder Mystery SQL Mystery Getting Started If you're confident in your SQL, you can skip these explanations and put your skills to the test! What's in the database? An ERD, which stands for Entity Relationship Diagram, is a visual representation of the tables in a database. Here's the ERD for the mystery database: If two tables are related, the matching columns, i.e. the ones you use in a JOIN, are connected by a gray arrow in the diagram.

<!doctype html> Challenge #7 Challenge #7 A special keyword has been assigned to you, encrypted with your RSA public key. There are many different keywords, but you will only receive one. You can find your encrypted keyword here (listed alphabetically by LAUSD email name): 8th Grade Keywords 7th Grade Keywords The number of words is a secret, but to solve the final (?) challenge, you'll need all of them.

<!doctype html> Challenge #6 Challenge #6 Cyphertext:  This cyphertext has been created by using AES-128. To decrypt it, you can use this Python program. However, you'll need the decryption key. For AES-128, a key must be exactly 16 characters long (and that's how long the one you need is). The key is a combination of two 8 letter words. The first is your keyword from Challenge #3. The second is encoded here:
<!doctype html> Workshop Congratulations, you found the answer for "radiate"! Remember this number: 338
